#Text=Gagauzia
#Text=Gagauzia is an autonomous region of Moldova .
#Text=It has a population of about 135,000 people , 83 % of whom are of the Gagauz Turkic ethnic group .
#Text=History
#Text=According to some theories , the Gagauz people descend from the Seljuq Turks who settled in Dobruja following the Anatolian Seljuq Sultan Izzeddin Keykavus II ( 1236 – 1276 ) .
#Text=One clan of Oghuz Turks is known to have migrated to the Balkans during intertribal conflicts with other Turks .
#Text=This Oghuz Turk clan converted from Islam to Orthodox Christianity after settling in medieval Bulgaria and were called Gagauz Turks .
#Text=A large group of the Gagauz later left Bulgaria and settled in southern Bessarabia , along with a group of ethnic Bulgarians .
#Text=Between 1812 and 1846 , Russian Imperial authorities relocated the Gagauz people from what is today eastern Bulgaria to what is now Moldova .
#Text=In August 1989 , Moldavian ( Romanian ) was adopted as the official language of the Republic of Moldova , replacing Russian .
#Text=The Gagauz were also worried about the implications for them if Moldova reunited with Romania , as seemed likely at the time .
#Text=In August 1990 , Comrat declared itself an autonomous republic , but the Moldovan government annulled the declaration as unconstitutional .
#Text=Support for the Soviet Union remained high in Gagauzia , with a referendum in March 1991 returning an almost unanimous vote in favour of remaining part of the USSR .
#Text=Gagauzia declared itself an independent republic on 19 August 1991 .

#Text=But when the Moldovan parliament voted on independence from the Soviet Union on 27 August 1991 , six of the 12 Gagauz deputies in the Moldovan parliament voted in favour , while the other six abstained .
#Text=The Moldovan government began to pay more attention to minority rights .
#Text=In 1994 , the Parliament of Moldova awarded to " the people of Gagauzia " ( through the adoption of the new Constitution of Moldova ) the right of " external self-determination " .

column1: #Text=On 23 December 1994 , the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova accepted the " Law on the Special Legal Status of Gagauzia " , resolving the dispute peacefully .

column1: #Text=Gagauzia is now a " national-territorial autonomous unit " with three official languages : Romanian , Gagauz , and Russian .
#Text=On 2 February 2014 , Gagauzia held a referendum .
#Text=An overwhelming majority of voters opted for closer ties with Russia over integration into the European Union .
#Text=They also said they preferred the independence of Gagauzia if Moldova chooses to enter the EU .
#Text=People

#Text=Three cities and 23 communes were included in the Autonomous Gagauz Territory : all localities with more than 50 % ethnic Gagauz in population , and those localities with between 40 % and 50 % Gagauz which expressed their desire by referendum to be included to determine Gagauzia 's borders .
#Text=Geography
#Text=Gagauzia is composed of four enclaves within Moldova .
#Text=The main , central enclave includes the cities Comrat and Ceadîr-Lunga .
#Text=The second largest enclave is the area around and including the city of Vulcănești , while two smaller enclaves are the villages of Copceac and Carbalia .
#Text=Cities
#Text=- The capital of Gagauzia
#Text=- The second-largest city in Gagauzia
#Text=By car
#Text=Comrat is 100 km south of Chisinau .
#Text=It is also possible to get day tours of Moldova from Chisinau that will include a visit to Gagauzia .
#Text=By bus
#Text=From Chisinau , take a bus to Valea Perjei ( 1 hr 18 min , every 30 minutes ) , and change to another bus to Comrat ( 50 min , every 2 hours ) .
#Text=Visa and borders
#Text=Gagauzia is a part of Moldova ; no separate visa is required
